title: 107_s2187
content: The Act titled "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002" authorizes the Department to provide health care during major disasters and medical emergencies. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide hospital care and medical services during major disasters and emergencies under the "Department of Veterans Affairs Emergency Medical Care Act of 2002." The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide care and services to veterans during disasters or emergencies declared by the President or when the National Disaster Medical System is activated, regardless of their enrollment status. During disasters or emergencies, the Disaster Medical System can provide care and services to veterans without considering their enrollment status. Priority is given to veterans with service-connected disabilities and active-duty members of the Armed Forces receiving health-care services under a specific section. During disasters or emergencies, the Disaster Medical System can provide care and services to veterans without considering their enrollment status, with priority given to veterans with service-connected disabilities and active-duty members of the Armed Forces. Reimbursement for care provided to officers or employees of other Federal agencies is based on agreed-upon rates between the Secretary and the head of the respective department or agency. Amounts received by the Department under this reimbursement process are specified in the subsection. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary shall provide care and services to veterans, with reimbursement rates agreed upon with other Federal agencies. Amounts received will be credited to the Department facility that provided the care. Within 60 days of a disaster, the Secretary must report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary must report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within 60 days regarding the allocation of facilities and personnel for providing care and services. Regulations governing the Secretary's authority under this section shall be prescribed. During major disasters and medical emergencies, charges for emergency care may be waived as per Section 1711A. Members of the Armed Forces are provided with care during periods of war or national emergencies involving armed conflict. During war or national emergencies, the Secretary can provide hospital care and medical services to active duty members of the Armed Forces. In disasters or emergencies, care can also be provided to those responding to or involved in the situation. During disasters or emergencies, the Secretary can provide hospital care and medical services to active duty members of the Armed Forces. This includes those responding to or involved in the situation, with a higher priority given to furnishing care. The Emergency Assistance Act allows the Secretary to prioritize providing hospital care and medical services during disasters or emergencies, with a focus on the National Disaster Medical System. This takes precedence over care for other eligible groups, except for veterans with service-connected disabilities.
